questions.text: 1. A child presented with fatigue and delayed developmental milestones. He is found to have megaloblastic anaemia that does not respond to treatment with iron, folic acid, vitamin B12 or pyridoxine. He also has elevated levels of orotic acid in the urine. Which among the following will alleviate the symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette points towards a diagnosis of orotic aciduria which can be treated with Uridine.

Uridine is a pyrimidine nucleoside that can be useful in treating orotic aciduria as it bypasses the missing activity in the pathway and can be converted to UTP, which, via feedback inhibition, prevents the accumulation of orotic acid.

Orotic aciduria is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in uridine monophosphate (UMP) synthase. This enzyme contains two activities, orotate phosphoribosyltransferase and orotidine decarboxylase. The lack of pyrimidines impairs nucleic acid synthesis needed for hematopoiesis, explaining the megaloblastic anemia in this infant.

Orotic acid accumulates and spills into the urine, resulting in orotic acid crystals and orotic acid urinary obstruction. The presence of orotic acid in urine might suggest that the defect could be ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency, but the lack of hyperammonemia rules out a defect in the urea cycle.

Adenine, Guanine and hypoxanthine are purines and thus their supplementation will not help alleviate symptoms of Orotic aciduria, which is a disorder of the Pyrimidine synthesis pathway.



A defect in the enzymes of pyrimidine synthesis can give rise to the following conditions:

Enzyme deficiency  Disorder Features
Uridine-5-monophosphate synthase Hereditary orotic aciduria Megaloblastic anaemia, growth retardation, neurologic abnormalities, crystalluria, obstructive uropathy
Pyrimidine-5-nucleotidase  Hemolytic anemia Basophilic stippling of erythrocytes, high levels of cytidine and uridine ribonucleotides 
Dihydroprimidine dehydrogenase  Convulsive disorders, motor retardation, and mental retardation increased urinary excretion of uracil, thymine

questions.text: 2. A 20 year old male patient with an autosomal dominant familial dyslipidemia comes to the hospital with acute pancreatitis. His lab reports shows triglyceride level of 1100 mg/dl, cholesterol - 143 mg/dl, VLDL - 206 mg/dl, HDL - 39 mg/dl. The overproduced lipoprotein has all of the following except?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical finding and lab values are suggestive of Type IV hypertriglyceridemia.

The overproduced lipoprotein is VLDL which has apolipoprotein E, C-II and B-100, but not apo A-I. Apo A-I is present in HDL and chylomicrons.

Functions of apolipoprotein:

* Apo E - mediates remnant uptake(except LDL)

* Apo A-I - activates LCAT(lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase)

* Apo C-II - lipoprotein lipase cofactor

* Apo B-100 - binds LDL receptor

* Apo B-48 - mediates chylomicron secretion into the lymphatics

questions.text: 3. A patient underwent an imaging study; the findings are shown in the image given below. Which of the following compounds is used for this investigation?
questions.solution:
Fluorodeoxyglucose is used for the given investigation.

The image shows a positron-emission tomography (PET) scan. PET involves the use of a radiolabeled bio-compound such as 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is injected intravenously. This compound is taken up and broken down in the cells.

It is based on the principle that tumor cells have a high metabolic rate and can metabolize FDG. However, tumor cells can metabolize FDG only to FDG-6-phosphate, and no further. Hence, it accumulates in tumor cells and can be detected and quantified.

Other tracers:

* 18F or 11C-choline

* 18F-fluorothymidine(FLT)

* 11C-acetate

* 11C-metheonoine

* 18F-miisonidazole(FMISO)

PET provides information on tumor proliferation, lipogenesis, amino acid metabolism, angiogenesis, and hypoxia. Good anatomical localization is possible with hybrid imaging techniques like PET/CT and PRT/MR.

Clinically, cancer cells exhibiting the Warburg effect show a property of glucose hunger. This is used to visualize them via positron emission tomography (PET) scanning.

Unlike normal cells, which mainly rely on oxidative phosphorylation for efficient ATP production, neoplastic cells preferentially metabolize glucose through glycolysis, producing lactate even in the presence of oxygen. Although glycolysis yields far less ATP (2 vs. 36 from oxidative phosphorylation), it preserves carbon intermediates that can be diverted into lipid and protein synthesis. This metabolic adaptation provides the building blocks required for the rapid growth and proliferation of cancer cells.

questions.text: 4. A 2-week-old preterm infant presents with a history of blood in her diapers. Her PT and aPTT are prolonged, but platelets are normal. The intrinsic deficiency of which of the following produces these symptoms in this newborn?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of hemorrhagic disease of newborn secondary to menaquinone deficiency.

The 2-week-old preterm infant with blood in diapers with prolonged PT, aPTT and normal platelets is most likely suffering from haemorrhagic disease of newborn due to the intrinsic deficiency of Vitamin K produced by intestinal flora, i.e. menaquinone.

Vitamin K exists as three biologically active compounds- phylloquinone (dietary source in green vegetables), menaquinone (synthesised by intestinal bacteria), menadione, and menadiol diacetate are synthetic compounds that are metabolised to phylloquinone.

Newborns, especially preterm infants, lack intestinal flora for endogenous synthesis of vitamin K and, hence, solely rely on exogenous vitamin K. Breast milk is deficient in free vitamin K, which makes them prone to vitamin K deficiency. Maternal use of vitamin K antagonists like warfarin, phenytoin, and primidone can also cause severe haemorrhagic disease, causing severe systemic bleeding, ecchymoses in the 1st week of life with bleeding from the gastrointestinal tract, umbilical stump, nasal, or intracranial bleeding.

questions.text: 5. A 65-year-old postmenopausal woman was diagnosed with osteoporosis four months back and was started on oral bisphosphonates. Which among the following is a biochemical marker of bone resorption that can be used to monitor her response to treatment?

choices.text: Serum propeptide of type I procollagen

questions.solution:
Serum and urine cross-linked C-telopeptide is a marker of bone resorption while the others are markers of bone formation.

Collagen 1 forms the majority of the organic bone matrix. Cross-linked C-telopeptide is a breakdown product of collagen that gets released into circulation during bone turnover. 

The measurement of bone resorption using markers like serum cross-linked C-telopeptide before initiating therapy and 3–6 months after starting therapy provides an earlier estimate of patient response than bone densitometry evaluations. 

Biochemical markers measure the overall state of bone remodeling at a single point in time. They are primarily used for monitoring the response to treatment. Markers of bone resorption also help in the prediction of fracture risk in older individuals. 

Biochemical Markers of Bone Metabolism include:

Bone formation markers:

* Serum propeptide of type I procollagen

* Serum osteocalcin 

* Serum bone-specific alkaline phosphatase 

Bone resorption markers:

* Urine and serum cross-linked N-telopeptide 

* Urine and serum cross-linked C-telopeptide.

questions.text:
6. A 45-year-old male patient presents with recent onset of photosensitivity and development of vesicles and bullae on the sun-exposed areas of his skin as shown below. A urine analysis showed the presence of elevated levels of uroporphyrin I and normal red cell uroporphyrin. Identify the false statement regarding the patient's illness.

UROD- Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase

choices.text: Low dose hydroxychloroquine is used in management
Associated with increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding the patient's illness is that the hepatic iron stores are normal. 

The given clinical scenario of a patient developing photosensitive dermopathy, urine analysis showing elevated levels of uroporphyrin I and normal red cell uroporphyrin, points to a diagnosis of porphyria cutanea tarda.

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the most common type of porphyria and presents with cutaneous and hepatic features. It is caused due to a deficiency in the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, which converts uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III. Mutations of the uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD) gene (Option A) are present in the familial type PCT.

The accumulated porphyrins are transported to the skin and act as photosensitizers. Hence, the patients usually present with skin friability, milia, and bullae on the sun-exposed skin of the dorsal aspect of the hands, forearms, face, legs, and feet. Hypertrichosis, mottled pigmentary change, and scleroderma-like induration are associated features.

The porphyrins accumulate in the liver and are excreted in urine and bile. Hepatic iron stores are increased as PCT is an iron-related disorder. Liver dysfunction is common in these patients and the risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma is increased(Option D). 

Diagnosis is made by the classical clinical feature of photosensitivity with elevated urine, stool, and plasma uroporphyrin with normal red cell uroporphyrin. 

Treatment: Repeated phlebotomies to deplete hepatic iron stores. Iron administration can lead to a recurrence of the disease. Low-dose hydroxychloroquine(Option C) can be used. It forms complexes and removes the excess porphyrins from the liver.

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

* Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.

* Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: 7. A young boy with a metabolic disorder has long slender fingers, tall stature, and a high arched palate. He is fair-skinned, with blue eyes and a malar flush. On ophthalmological examination, there is a bilateral inferonasal subluxation of the lens. This disorder is due to abnormal metabolism of:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of homocystinuria, which is due to the abnormal metabolism of methionine.

Homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of methionine metabolism. It is due to a defect in the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase whose function is to convert homocysteine to cystathionine. This leads to an abnormal accumulation of homocysteine and its metabolites (homocysteine, homocysteine-cysteine complex, and others) in blood and urine, along with low levels of cysteine in plasma.



Clinical features: The affected infants appear normal at birth. Ectopia lentis occurs first at 3 years of age, causing severe myopia and iridodonesis. Progressive intellectual disability, psychiatric, and behavioral disorders are commonly seen. Thromboembolic events of small and large vessels of the brain can occur at any age.

Skeletal abnormalities resemble Marfan's syndrome. They are often tall and thin with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly. Scoliosis, a high arched palate, and crowding of teeth are also commonly observed.  These individuals may also exhibit blue eyes, fair skin, and malar flush.

Diagnosis is by elevated levels of methionine and homocysteine in body fluids. Additional tests include molecular analysis of cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) and enzyme assay in cultured fibroblasts, lymphocytes, or liver biopsy specimens. Treatment includes restriction of methionine intake and supplementation with cysteine, betaine, vitamins B6, and folate.

questions.text:
8. MR spectroscopy graph of a child with developmental delay shows the below finding.
What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The given MR spectroscopy image shows a peak in NAA levels ( N-acetyl aspartate) which is characteristic of Canavan’s disease. The peak is abnormally high due to decreased catabolization of NAA.

Canavan disease is an autosomal recessive leukodystrophy that occurs with higher frequency in individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish descent characterized by excessive urinary loss of NAA and spongy degeneration of white matter. It occurs due to a deficiency of the Aspartoacylase enzyme secondary to ASPA gene mutation.

Clinically, infants appear normal till 3-6 months of life when they start showing signs of progressive macrocephaly, delayed milestones, hypotonia, and head lag. Disease progression results in poor weight gain and feeding difficulties, spasticity, joint stiffness, and the development of optic atrophy and seizures. 

MRI shows diffuse white matter atrophy in the cerebral hemispheres with sparing of the brainstem and cerebellum. MR Spectroscopy shows a high peak of NAA, which is strongly suggestive of Canavan's disease. Elevated levels of NAA in blood, urine, CSF, and brain tissue can also be measured to come to a diagnosis. Enzymatic analysis of Aspartoacylase from fibroblasts is used to confirm the diagnosis.



MR spectroscopy is a non-invasive means of obtaining metabolic information. The image below shows a normal MR spectroscopy.



Metabolite Significance Clinical relevance
N-acetyl aspartate (NAA) Neuronal and axonal integrity Decreased in neuronal loss or damage
Creatinine Cellular ATP metabolism; energy stores Stable cerebral metabolite; used as an internal reference for other peaks
Choline Cellular proliferation Elevated in tumors and inflammatory processes
Lactate Anaerobic metabolism Presence indicates glycolysis end product; a marker of hypoxia
Lipid peak Fat contamination or necrosis May arise from scalp fat contamination; also seen in necrosis due to infection or tumour
Myo-inositol Gliosis and reactive astrocytosis Elevated in conditions with astrocytic proliferation

questions.text: 9. A female patient presents with headache and vomiting. On examination, papilledema was noted. She was sent for a head CT scan, which showed no intracranial mass. Which of the following is the likely cause of such presentation?
questions.solution:
The likely cause of the presentation given above is Vitamin A toxicity.

The clinical features of intracranial hypertension manifesting as papilledema, vomiting, and headache but without an intracranial mass, point towards a diagnosis of pseudotumor cerebri or idiopathic intracranial hypertension, which is caused by vitamin A toxicity.

Toxicity occurs when the accumulation of vitamin A goes beyond the capacity of intracellular binding proteins. The unbound vitamin A causes membrane lysis and tissue damage.

Clinical features of hypervitaminosis A:

* CNS - Headache, nausea, ataxia, anorexia, increased cerebrospinal fluid pressure aka pseudotumor cerebri

* Liver - Hepatomegaly and hyperlipidemia.

* Bones - Thickening of the long bones, hypercalcemia, soft tissue calcification.

* Dermatological - Dryness, desquamation, alopecia

* Teratogenesis - It can cause congenital malformations in the developing fetus. Isotretinoin is a teratogenic drug contraindicated in women of childbearing age unless indicated.

Other options:

Option A: Pyridoxine toxicity causes sensory neuropathy, imbalance, numbness, and muscle weakness

Option B: Niacin toxicity leads to dilatation of blood vessels, flushing, histamine release, and skin irritation, Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, which is characterized by dermatitis, dementia, and diarrhea.

Option C: Thiamine deficiency causes Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is a triad of ophthalmoplegia, global confusion, and ataxia.

Pearl PM2180: Hypervitaminosis A

Hypervitaminosis A:

* Vitamin A excess can present as two forms: vitamin A toxicity and carotenaemia.

*  Hypervitaminosis A results from overconsumption of non‐prescription nutritional supplements, prescription medications containing vitamin A derivatives and foods high in vitamin A.

* Carotenaemia is a benign disorder caused by excessive β‐carotene intake.

* In carotenaemia, carotenes are excreted from sebaceous glands and sweat glands, and ultimately deposit in the stratum corneum. This results in carotenoderma.

* Acute vitamin A toxicity manifests with headaches, vision changes, fatigue, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, myalgias and arthralgias. Weight loss can be observed with chronic intoxication.

* Individuals with chronic hypervitaminosis A have dry and scaly skin, desquamation, cheilitis, alopecia, follicular hyperkeratosis and hyperpigmentation, associated pseudotumor cerebri and skeletal changes (premature closure of the epiphyses and pathological bone fractures).

* Prognosis:

* Vitamin A toxicity: discontinuation of vitamin A leads to resolution of almost all symptoms of vitamin A toxicity, with the exception of cirrhosis and sequelae related to pseudotumour cerebri.

* Carotenaemia: Excellent prognosis with no clear long‐term adverse effects. Pigmentary changes resolve within weeks to months of decreasing β‐carotene intake.

questions.text: 10. An infant seems normal at birth but develops breathing difficulties shortly after birth with feeding problems, vomiting, and hypotonia. His urine was found to have a characteristic smell of tomcat urine. Considering the most likely diagnosis, treatment of this child with ______ will result in a dramatic clinical and biochemical response?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, treatment with biotin will result in a dramatic clinical and biochemical response.

The scenario given above of a child with breathing difficulty, hypotonia, vomiting, and tomcat urine odor is suggestive of Multiple Carboxylase Deficiency, which is effectively managed by supplementing biotin.

Multiple carboxylase deficiency occurs due to a defect in recycling of biotin (Biotinidase deficiency) or inability to utilize biotin to activate holocarboxylase (Holocarboxylase synthetase deficiency). 

In the neonatal form of the disease, clinically, the affected infants seem normal at birth, but develop breathing difficulties shortly after birth with feeding problems, vomiting, and hypotonia. If untreated, generalized erythematous rash, exfoliation, alopecia, failure to thrive, seizures, and even coma may occur. Urine may have a peculiar odour which has been described as tomcat urine.

In case of holocarboxylase synthetase deficiency, biotin (10-20mg/day) supplementation promotes activation of the deficient enzyme, while in Biotinidase deficiency, defective recycling is overcome with the help of supplementation of 5-20mg of biotin/day. Other enzymatic reactions that require biotin include:

* Acetyl CoA carboxylase

* Propionyl CoA carboxylase

* Pyruvate carboxylase

* methyl crotonyl CoA carboxylase

questions.text: 11. A 4-year-old male child came to the hospital for treatment of acute leukemia. He suffers from a rare congenital disorder known as Bloom syndrome. What is the defective mechanism that has caused the disorder?

choices.text: Defective non homologous end joining repair

questions.solution:
Defective homologous repair is the cause of the disorder in the given clinical scenario.  

Bloom syndrome is a rare congenital disorder associated with defective homologous repair, and patients with this disorder are at risk of developing acute leukemia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by the loss of function mutations in a helicase that is needed for a homologous recombination repair. The individuals have developmental anomalies and are at increased risk for developing different types of cancers.

Other options:

Option A: Defective Nonhomologous End-Joining Repair (NHEJ) is seen in severe combined immunodeficiency disease.  It comprises a group of genetically distinct syndromes, having defects in cell-mediated and humoral immunity. Affected infants present with thrush, diaper rash, and failure to thrive.

Option C: Defective DNA mismatch repair is associated with hereditary non-polyposis colonic cancer (HNPCC). It is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with carcinomas of the colon and caecum. Affected individuals inherit an abnormal copy of the mismatch repair gene.

Option D: DNA nucleotide excision repair (NER) is defective in xeroderma pigmentosum. Inherited loss of function mutations in the genes responsible for the repair mechanisms gives rise to xeroderma pigmentosum. It is characterized by a high risk of skin cancers.

questions.text: 12. A 10-month-old male baby presents with vomiting, lethargy, and severe jaundice when weaning was started with fruit juice. Which of the following can give a positive reaction in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Seliwanoff's reagent will give a positive reaction in this patient's condition.

The appearance of vomiting, lethargy, and severe jaundice after initiation of fruit juice suggests a diagnosis of Hereditary fructose intolerance, which causes urinary excretion of fructose, thus showing a positive Seliwanoff test. 

Seliwanoff's test is used to distinguish between glucose and fructose. Seliwanoff's reagent is resorcinol in HCl. 3 ml of the reagent and 0.5 ml of urine are heated for 30 seconds up to a boiling point. A red color indicates the presence of fructose. 

Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) is due to a deficiency of the enzyme aldolase B. It is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism. Defective aldolase B causes the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate. This will inhibit glycogen phosphorylase and cause glycogen accumulation in the liver and associated hypoglycemia.

Symptoms occur when sucrose (fructose+glucose) is introduced into the diet of infants, usually around 6 months of age. Patients will present with vomiting, loss of appetite, and failure to thrive. Hepatomegaly and jaundice may occur. If liver damage progresses, death will occur. 

Fructose is also excreted in the urine. This gives a positive reducing sugar test (Benedict's test), a positive test for furfural derivatives, and specifically a positive Seliwanoff's test (for fructose). Withdrawal of fructose from the diet will immediately relieve the symptoms

Benedict's test detects the excretion of reducing substances in the urine. About 0.5 ml of urine is boiled with 5 ml of Benedict's reagent for 2 minutes. The formation of a precipitate is observed on cooling. The test is semi-quantitative and the color of the precipitate roughly parallels the concentration of reducing sugar. The blue color indicates the absence of sugar in the urine. The green precipitate means 0.5%, yellow (1%), orange (1.5%) and red indicates 2% or more sugar (1% means 1 g per 100 ml). 

Furfural test: Monosaccharides when treated with concentrated sulphuric acid undergo dehydration with the removal of 3 molecules of water. Hexoses give hydroxymethylfurfural and pentoses give furfural. The furfural derivative can condense with phenolic compounds to give colored products. This forms the basis of the Molisch test. It is a general test for carbohydrates. 

The image summarizes the metabolic pathways involved in the metabolism of fructose:



Other options:

questions.text: 13. The echocardiography report of a 35-year-old woman hailing from China indicates dilated cardiomyopathy. Which of the following conditions can explain her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient is probably suffering from Keshan's disease, which is due to selenium deficiency.

Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where dietary intake of selenium is low. Mainly dilated cardiomyopathy is characteristic, and may also result in cardiomegaly, congestive cardiac failure and fulminant cardiogenic shock.

Selenium is an important trace element that is a part of the 21st amino acid selenocysteine. There are many selenium-containing enzymes such as:

* Glutathione peroxidase

* De-iodinase

* Thioredoxin reductase

Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant that complements the role of vitamin E. Availability of vitamin E reduces the selenium requirement. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, muscle meat, and some cereals.

questions.text: 14. A baby is brought to the OPD with complaints of lethargy and poor feeding. On examination, it is noted that the urine had a smell of burnt sugar. A defect in which of the following enzymes causes this disease?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is maple syrup urine disease (MSUD), which occurs due to a defect of the enzyme branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase.

MSUD is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to a deficiency of branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase complex. This impairs the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids valine, leucine, isoleucine, and alloisoleucine. These amino acids, particularly leucine and its metabolite accumulate in the blood, causing toxic effects on the brain.

The affected child develops poor feeding and vomiting a few days after birth. There is a period of hypertonicity with a period of flaccidity in between. These appear as repetitive boxing and bicycling movements. The babies may also have hypoglycemia, but this is not corrected by the administration of glucose. The urine, sweat, and cerumen of the baby have a sweetish maple syrup-like odor.

Laboratory investigations will show increased levels of branched-chain amino acids in the plasma and urine. Leucine levels are usually higher than isoleucine, valine, and alloisoleucine. Since the patient excretes ketone bodies in the urine, the urine will be positive for the dinitrophenylhydrazine test.

Treatment involves controlled intake of branched-chain amino acids using commercially available formulas and judicious supplementation of isoleucine and valine. Very high levels of leucine are removed by hemodialysis.

questions.text: 15. A patient with a history of chest pain has elevated troponin I and Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH) but normal Creatine Kinase Myocardial Band (CK-MB). Approximately, how many days ago did he have the myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
This patient, who has elevated troponin I and LDH but normal CK-MB had an MI approximately 6 days back.  

CPK-MB starts to rise by 4-6 hours and returns to baseline by 2-3 days. So Option A can be ruled out because before 2-3 days, CK-MB will also be elevated. Troponin I returns to baseline in around 10 days and by 10 days, LDH also returns to baseline. Hence, Option B and D can be ruled out. Hence, the most appropriate answer is 6 days.

Troponin I and Troponin T are specific markers of myocardial infarction and they rise rapidly incase of an acute infarct. They rise to a diagnostic level at 12 to 16 hours after an infarct and peak 24 to 32 hours after the event. Following reperfusion the levels may still be higher. 

Creatine kinase Myocardial band (CK MB) - Although the levels of CK MB rise 4 to 8 hours after an infarct it is not specific to the disease as their levels are raised in other conditions such as muscular disorder or trauma including intramuscular injections. 

Myoglobulin rises within 2 hours of onset of symptoms and remains for 7 to 12 hours. 

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) - LDH is leaked following cell death in a myocardial tissue and is a sensitive marker of the disease and the onset is 72 hours after the infarction but lasts till 10 days.

questions.text: 16. A child accidentally consumed pesticide which had fluoroacetate as one of the ingredients. Which of the following enzymes in TCA cycle are likely to be inhibited in this child?
questions.solution:
Aconitase is the enzyme inhibited in the given clinical scenario. 

Fluroacetate inhibits the enzyme aconitase in a non-competitive manner, which affects the conversion of citrate to iso citrate(A). Fluroacetate is found in some plants, and Anticancer drugs are metabolized to fluroacetyl-CoA, which condenses with oxaloacetate to form flurocitrate, with aconitase causing citrate to accumulate

Other inhibitors of the TCA cycle:

* Arsenite inhibits the conversion of α-ketoglutarate to succinyl-CoA by non-competitively inhibiting α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase(A).

* Malonate inhibits the enzyme succinate dehydrogenase in a competitive manner. which affects the conversion of succinate to fumarate.

questions.text: 17. A 50-year-old man diagnosed with type-2 diabetes mellitus is being treated with metformin. Failing to supplement with vitamins may result in a deficiency manifestation that would correspond to which specific regions of the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
A vitamin  B12 deficiency is most likely in this patient, represented by Image D which shows involvement of the dorsal columns and the lateral corticospinal tract.

Subacute combined degeneration (SACD) is due to the deficiency of vitamin B12. Pernicious anemia, partial gastrectomy, and Diphyllobothrium latum infestation can lead to this condition. The most severely affected regions in SACD are the posterior columns at the cervical and upper thoracic levels as well as the lateral corticospinal tracts and the cerebral cortex.

Required daily allowance of B12 1–2 mcg/day. Pregnant and lactating mothers require to consume 2mg/day. 

Patients with subacute combined degeneration (SACD) commonly present with loss of vibration sense and proprioception, along with paresthesias in the hands and feet. Peripheral neuropathy resulting in loss of reflex in a patient with a positive Babinski sign is a diagnostic clue. Advanced cases often show optic atrophy, cognitive and psychiatric manifestations. 

MRI spine shows myelopathy and areas of demyelination. Myelopathy of SACD tends to be diffuse rather than focal and involves the dorsal column prominently, seen as an inverted V-sign on transverse section MRI. The below image shows MRI of SACD in longitudinal and transverse sections:





Treatment is replacement therapy with 1000 μg of intramuscular vitamin B12 repeated at regular intervals or by oral vitamin  B12. Regimen is 1000 μg of intramuscular  B12 daily for 1 week , then weekly for one month and monthly for the remainder of the patient's life. Oral  B12 is not given to patients with neurological disease.

Other images:

Image A: The anterior horn of the spinal cord is highlighted in green in this image. Spinal muscular atrophy is a genetic disease characterized by progressive degeneration of anterior horn cells, which results in weakness. 

Image B : Image B correctly represents the areas of the spinal cord affected by amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The pathologic hallmark of ALS is the death of the affected lower motor neurons (LMN) consisting of the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord and their homologues in the brainstem, upper motor neurons (UMN) consisting of the corticospinal tract and corticobulbar tract originating in the motor cortex. Image B has the anterior horn of the spinal cord and the corticospinal tracts highlighted in green.

Image C: The dorsal column and dorsal root of the spinal cord are highlighted in green in this image. Tabes dorsalis (or syphilitic myelopathy) is a slow degeneration and demyelination of the neural tracts seen in tertiary syphilis, primarily involving the dorsal columns of the spinal cord, dorsal roots, and dorsal root ganglia.

questions.text: 18. An Indian tourist who has come to Jamaica consumes a local unripe fruit. Following its consumption, he develops severe vomiting, confusion, and hypoglycemia. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Impaired omega oxidation of fatty acids
Hypoglycin is the toxin responsible for this condition
Excretion of dicarboxylic acids in the urine

questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is Jamaican vomiting sickness which occurs due to impaired beta-oxidation of fatty acids and not impaired omega oxidation (Option B). In fact, some reports suggest that omega oxidation becomes prominent.

It is caused due to consumption of an unripe ackee fruit, which has the toxins hypoglycin A and B (Option C). Hypoglycin inactivates medium and short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (Option A), inhibiting β-oxidation and causing nonketotic hypoglycemia. There is the excretion of dicarboxylic acid (Option D) in the urine.

Patients present with profuse vomiting, altered mental status, and hypoglycemia. Treatment is primarily supportive care with intravenous fluids and dextrose.

questions.text: 19. A 30-year-old male patient complains of fatigue and weight loss for the past 1 year. Examination revealed massive splenomegaly. Chromosomal analysis was done and the defect is shown below. Which is the most sensitive test to detect this type of defect?
questions.solution:
The most sensitive test to detect the type of defect shown in the image is Spectral karyotyping.

The given image shows t(9:22) and BCR-ABL fusion, along with features of fatigue, weight loss, and massive splenomegaly suggesting a diagnosis of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). The most sensitive investigation to detect this translocation defect is spectral karyotyping (SKY) or multicolor FISH. 

CML is a myeloproliferative neoplasm that presents as fatigue, anemia, splenomegaly, weight loss, and anorexia. The image demonstrates the Philadelphia chromosome, a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. BCR-ABL gene created by this reciprocal (9;22) (q34;q11) translocation is characteristic of CML. It is detected using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) or PCR.

Fluorescent in Situ Hybridisation (FISH) is a technique for the detection of specific genetic information on morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes. It uses DNA probes that recognize sequences specific to particular chromosomal regions. Multicolor FISH uses 23 distinct fluorescent colors, thus each chromosome is identified by a unique color, and translocations are detected easily.

G banding (Option A) is a method used for karyotyping and chromosomal identification using Geimsa stain. It cannot detect small translocations but is used for detecting aneuploidies.

Southern blotting(Option C) is used to detect specific  DNA sequences using complementary DNA probes and is not used for the diagnosis of CML.

DNA sequencing(Option D) is used to detect Mendelian disorders, cancers, acute myeloid leukemia, etc. It is the sequencing of the whole genome and is done using Sangers sequencing or Next Generation Sequencing. It is not employed for the diagnosis of CML in patients.

Image of a multicolor FISH/Spectral Karyotyping:



Pearl PM1019: Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH)



It is a simple technique for the detection of specific genetic information on a morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes.

The fluorescent probes are added to cells usually arrested in the metaphase stage of cell division (when every chromosome is separately).

Types of FISH:

1) Chromosomal painting: Each chromosome is identified by using a different colour of the fluorescent probe, however, each chromosome does not have a unique colour. Since the fluorescent dyes are limited.

2) Multicolour FISH: 23 distinct fluorescent colours made by mixing 5 fluorophores. Thus each chromosome is identified by a unique colour. It is also known as spectral karyotyping (SKY). It offers various advantages such as

* Detects structural and numeric abnormalities in chromosomes.

* Detects gene amplification and subtle microdeletions

* Maps a newly isolated gene to its correct chromosomal loci

However, this process requires prior knowledge of the genes and chromosomes.

3) Interphase FISH: It is a rapid procedure of FISH, wherein growing cells are not needed. It is used in prenatal diagnosis and in tumour diagnosis.

The image shown is of a Multicolor FISH also known as Spectral karyotyping with a unique colour to each chromosome pair.

questions.text: 20. An 8-year-old boy is brought with severe pain in his right thigh which has worsened over the last few months. He also has frequent nose bleeds and gets fatigued easily while playing. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and leukocyte assay shows low levels of beta-glucosidase activity. What is the inheritance pattern of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of bone pain, epistaxis, hepatosplenomegaly, and low levels of β-glucosidase suggests a diagnosis of Gaucher's disease that is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

Gaucher's disease is an inborn error of metabolism due to the deficiency of the enzyme acid β-glucosidase. This leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide in the cells of the reticuloendothelial system.

The clinical features result from the accumulation of lipid-laden macrophages in the spleen, liver, bone marrow, bone, and other tissues. It is characterized by hematologic abnormalities, organomegaly, and skeletal involvement like bone pain and pathological fractures. There are 3 clinical subtypes :

Type 1 - presents from early childhood to late adulthood. These patients present with hepatosplenomegaly, pathological fractures resulting in Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the distal femur, and thrombocytopenia.

Type 2 - acute neuronopathic form. These patients have a rapid neurodegenerative course and present with increased tone, strabismus, and organomegaly. These patients die within 1 year of life.

Type 3 - juvenile or subacute neuronopathic form. It presents in childhood, and there is death by 10-15 years of age.

Gaucher cells are the pathological hallmark of the disease. They are seen in the reticuloendothelial system, especially in the bone marrow. It has a wrinkled paper appearance due to the presence of intracytoplasmic inclusions. The cytoplasm of the Gaucher cell is strongly PAS-positive.

Gaucher's disease is treated with enzyme replacement therapy with Imiglucerase. An image of a Gaucher cell showing a crumpled tissue paper appearance due to the accumulation of massive amounts of glucocerebrosides within the phagocytes is given below.



Erlenmeyer flask deformity also known as metaphyseal flaring is a radiographic appearance typically on a femoral radiograph demonstrating relative constriction of the diaphysis and flaring of the metaphysis.
